Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from 6 fragments) of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; alternating lotus flowers and palmettes in added white outline with added red centres, above short vertical stroke pattern between red and white bands; top of rim glazed; exterior: alternating red and black tongues below rim above zigzag band between pairs of dilute lines; below, painted decoration consisting of animal frieze (from left, part of rump and tail of undetermined animal or figure to left; at right, head,with red hair, face and neck, in white, and dotted chest and wing of sphinx to left); pendant triangle, short vertical strokes, elaborate rosettes and dotted squares as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1888,0601.465.a and Paris , Louvre E8056 bis.22 and belongs to the same vase as 1888,0601.465.b, 1888,0601.465.c, 1888,0601.465.d, 1888,0601.465.e, Paris E8056 bis.22, London UCL 751 and UCL 393 and Boston 88.830. The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1965,0930.338. Lemos describes the sherd as coming from a mediocre, but big chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice kraters. Chalices in this group display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1).
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 90, p. 263, no. 552, pl. 69)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1572) (phase 2)
